"Kesepakatan dagang besar kami dengan Jepang baru saja dimulai! Skala proyek ini sangat besar, dan tidak mungkin terwujud tanpa satu kata yang sangat istimewa, tarif," tulis Trump dalam unggahan di media sosialnya sebagaimana dilansir dari Bloomberg, Rabu (18/2/2026).

Perdana Menteri Jepang Sanae Takaichi menyatakan investasi tersebut dirancang untuk membangun rantai pasok yang tangguh melalui kerja sama di sektor-sektor strategis bagi keamanan ekonomi, termasuk mineral kritis, energi, dan kecerdasan buatan (artificial intelligence/AI).

“Kami meyakini inisiatif ini sepenuhnya selaras dengan tujuan utamanya: mendorong manfaat timbal balik bagi Jepang dan Amerika Serikat, menjamin keamanan ekonomi, serta memacu pertumbuhan,” ujarnya.

Investasi terbesar akan difokuskan pada pembangunan fasilitas gas alam di Ohio yang diperkirakan mampu menghasilkan listrik hingga 9,2 gigawatt (GW), menurut pernyataan Menteri Perdagangan AS Howard Lutnick. Trump menyebut proyek ini sebagai yang terbesar dalam sejarah.

Jepang diproyeksikan menanamkan US$33 miliar pada proyek tersebut, yang akan dipimpin anak usaha SoftBank Group Corp., yakni SB Energy.

Baca Juga : Prabowo Bertemu Trump, Industri Tekstil Berharap Keringanan Tarif dari AS

Jika beroperasi penuh, kapasitas pembangkit tersebut setara dengan sembilan reaktor nuklir atau mencukupi kebutuhan listrik sekitar 7,4 juta rumah tangga pada jaringan listrik terbesar di AS yang dikelola PJM Interconnection LLC.

Proyek kedua mencakup fasilitas ekspor minyak mentah laut dalam di Teluk Meksiko. Investasi senilai US$2,1 miliar akan dialokasikan untuk terminal ekspor Texas GulfLink yang dioperasikan Sentinel Midstream. Fasilitas tersebut diperkirakan mampu menghasilkan ekspor minyak mentah AS hingga US$30 miliar per tahun saat beroperasi penuh.

Selain itu, Jepang juga akan berinvestasi pada fasilitas manufaktur berlian industri sintetis di Georgia. Proyek senilai US$600 juta itu melibatkan Element Six, anak usaha De Beers. Berlian sintetis dinilai sebagai komponen penting dalam produksi industri dan teknologi canggih.

Kepala Sekretaris Kabinet Jepang, Minoru Kihara, memastikan kedua pemerintah akan terus berkoordinasi guna merampungkan detail teknis dan mempercepat realisasi proyek.

Terkait Kesepakatan Tarif 15%

Pengumuman ini menjadi tonggak penting dalam implementasi pakta dagang yang diumumkan Trump tahun lalu. Di bawah kesepakatan tersebut, AS menetapkan tarif sebesar 15% untuk produk Jepang, termasuk penurunan bea masuk kendaraan— sektor krusial bagi perekonomian Jepang— sebagai imbal balik atas komitmen investasi US$550 miliar.

Pertemuan antara Trump dan Takaichi di Washington yang dijadwalkan pada 19 Maret mendatang diperkirakan akan menjadikan implementasi investasi sebagai agenda utama.

Menteri Perdagangan Jepang Ryosei Akazawa sebelumnya menegaskan proyek-proyek yang didanai tidak akan berisiko tinggi, melainkan berorientasi pada imbal hasil yang relatif aman. Dari total skema US$550 miliar, hanya sekitar 1%–2% yang akan berupa investasi tunai langsung, sementara sisanya dalam bentuk pinjaman dan penjaminan kredit.

Dalam pernyataannya, Lutnick menegaskan struktur pembiayaan dirancang agar Jepang memperoleh imbal hasil investasi, sementara AS mendapatkan aset strategis, perluasan kapasitas industri, serta penguatan dominasi energi.

Lonjakan permintaan listrik, terutama dari pusat data baru seiring booming AI, dinilai membuat investasi pembangkit listrik menjadi sangat relevan. Sebelumnya, kedua negara telah mengidentifikasi proyek potensial dengan nilai berkisar US$350 juta hingga US$100 miliar dalam kunjungan Trump ke Jepang tahun lalu, termasuk keterlibatan perusahaan seperti Toshiba Corp. dan Westinghouse.

Kesepakatan tersebut juga memuat ketentuan bahwa Jepang memiliki waktu 45 hari kerja untuk merealisasikan pendanaan setelah proyek dipilih. Jika batal mendanai, AS berhak menarik kembali sebagian pendapatan atau bahkan memberlakukan kembali tarif yang lebih tinggi. 

Trump sebelumnya sempat mengancam menaikkan tarif hingga 25% sebelum akhirnya menyepakati tarif 15% setelah Jepang meningkatkan komitmen investasi.

Analis senior Hudson Institute, William Chou, menilai ketiga proyek mencerminkan prioritas bersama AS dan Jepang di sektor energi, AI, dan semikonduktor, sekaligus sesuai dengan keunggulan industri Jepang di pasar AS.

“Pengumuman ini menjaga momentum politik menjelang kunjungan PM Takaichi ke Washington bulan depan dan menunjukkan bahwa Jepang adalah sekutu yang menepati komitmennya,” ujarnya.

title: Economic Transformation Progressing Slowly, Indonesian Manufacturing Spotlighted by World Bank
content:
Bisnis.com, JAKARTA -- Indonesia's economic transformation is proceeding slowly following the large contribution of the agricultural sector to the structure of Indonesia's gross domestic product (GDP). On the other hand, manufacturing's contribution to GDP is stuck at 19% and over the last 8 years, its contribution to GDP has never returned to 20%. Apart from that, manufacturing productivity is now being highlighted by the World Bank, aka the World Bank.

The World Bank in its latest report stated that behind the surge in investment in the last 5 years, the majority of capital flows flowed heavily to low value added sectors, thus contributing to the decline in national manufacturing productivity.

Based on the Country Growth & Jobs Report: Indonesia document released at the end of January 2026, the World Bank revealed that Indonesia's investment level has reached an average of 30% of Gross Domestic Product (GDP) in the last 15 years. "Nevertheless, around 70% of this investment flows into the low value-added manufacturing sector," wrote the World Bank in its report, quoted on Tuesday (17/2/2026).

This Washington DC-based institution noted that 70% of Indonesia's investment realization was sucked into the processed food industry, basic metals, as well as accommodation and food services due to the push of the commodity cycle.

Current conditions are inversely proportional to the flow of capital to export-oriented and high-value manufacturing, such as automotive, electronics, pharmaceuticals, and information and communications technology (ICT). In fact, the World Bank explains that these sectors became prime investment targets in the early to mid-1990s, driven by trade reform and deregulation.

The problem is, after that, there was a trend of market restrictions in the country. As a result, according to the World Bank, this phenomenon is the cause of the decline in Indonesia's manufacturing productivity by 20% to 30% compared to its glory era in the early 1990s.

Also Read

"Increasing market restrictions have protected leading companies and state-owned companies from competition, concentrating activity on low-value manufacturing and services," the report said.

The World Bank admits that the Indonesian government has not remained silent watching this decline through the ratification of the Job Creation Law in 2020 and various business regulatory reforms. The sweeping rules are designed to liberalize the business sector and loosen restrictions on foreign direct investment.

This step is acknowledged to have succeeded in triggering an increase in investment commitment in these sectors. However, the realization that came in turned out to be 'far from the fire'. "Actual investment flows are still far from expectations, largely due to various challenges in implementing [the Job Creation Law] in the field," explained the report.

According to Business records, the quality of investment continues to decline, at least when viewed from the perspective of employment. During 2025, the increase in investment will not be commensurate with the increase in labor absorption.

Based on data from the Ministry of Investment and Downstreaming/Investment Coordinating Board (BKPM), investment realization reached IDR 1,931.2 trillion throughout 2025. From this investment realization, employment reached 2,710,532 people.

Thus, every 1 worker absorbed requires an investment of around IDR 712.48 million.

When compared with the same period last year or throughout 2024, investment realization 'only' reached IDR 1,714.2 trillion (IDR 217 trillion or 12.66% lower than this year's realization). Nevertheless, employment reached 2,456,130 people.

Thus, every 1 person employed requires an investment of around IDR 698.1 million (cheaperly IDR 13.8 million).

This means that there is a decrease in the ratio of labor absorption to investment realization: labor absorption actually worsens when the value of direct investment grows positively.

Just for the record, the processing and agricultural industries are actually experiencing significant growth quite impressive in 2025. Both sectors recorded the highest growth records since 2015, namely above 5%.

The manufacturing sector or processing industry as a whole grew 5.3% (YoY) throughout 2025, higher than in 2024, namely 4.43%. Meanwhile, the agricultural sector's growth is very exponential, reaching 5.3%. Apart from the realization of economic growth, this figure has shot up from 2024 which was only 0.6%.

"If we look at the contribution to cumulative economic growth in 2025, in terms of the business sector, the processing industry is the source of the highest growth at 1.07%. This figure is the highest in the last four years," said Head of BPS Amalia Adininggar Widyasanti at a press conference, Thursday (5/2/2026).

Even though they recorded the highest growth records, the performance of the two sectors was not without records. The manufacturing sector, for example, grew when imports of raw materials fell and labor-intensive sectors came under pressure.

The pressure in the labor-intensive sector can be seen from the high number of layoffs and the increasingly ineffectiveness of investment in absorbing labor. The contribution of the manufacturing sector has never reached 20%, at least since 2018.

Meanwhile, the agricultural sector, which grew 5.33% (YoY) last year, has also become a source of economic growth. The figure was even the highest in four years, namely 0.60%. This source of growth has exceeded the 2022 level, which at that time was still 0.29%.

However, the high growth and contribution of the agricultural sector to GDP is not always encouraging news for the economy. The reason is, this can also be interpreted as a sign of stagnation in the process of transforming the Indonesian economy from an agrarian society towards industrialization.

Executive Director of the Institute for Development of Economics and Finance (Indef) Esther Sri Astuti believes that nothing has actually changed in the structure of the Indonesian economy, because agriculture has consistently been a large contributor to the Indonesian economy. The difference is that the manufacturing industry is acknowledged to be experiencing degradation.

"From the past, the agricultural sector has still contributed greatly, and the manufacturing industry has experienced degradation," he explained to Bisnis, Monday (16/2/2026).

In detail, Esther saw that high growth in the manufacturing sector did not reflect growth in the labor-intensive sector. In the field, it is acknowledged that sectors that are labor intensive or create large employment opportunities are still experiencing difficulties.

One of them is the textile sector. Esther sees that the challenges experienced by the textile sector come from various sides, from expensive raw materials to the onslaught of imported clothing.  "Even in the domestic market, we get attacks from a collection of products like China, right, which are much cheaper in price and better in quality. Well, that's China's strategy, right," said Esther to Bisnis, Monday (16/2/2026).

Not only as a result of the attack on imported clothes, Esther also highlighted fundamental problems in the textile sector. In terms of investment, the lecturer at the Faculty of Economics and Business, Diponegoro University (FEB Undip) also believes that the government needs to bring in more investors in the textile sector to create an ecosystem from upstream to downstream.

According to him, some entrepreneurs already have sophisticated production equipment. However, the quality is still less competitive with foreign industries when viewed from the perspective of human resource development.

"The problem with models, fashion, style, we have very few textile schools. Meanwhile in the US, from textile schools, from vocational schools to universities, they are complete, they already exist. Well, we only have textile schools. The fundamental problem must be corrected, if we want to make our textiles survive and return to their glory like in the 90s," he explained.

The Indonesian Employers' Association (Apindo) said that 9 of the 16 manufacturing subsectors were still growing h national average throughout 2025. This condition reflects the real pressure that business actors in the real sector are still feeling.

General Chairperson of Apindo Shinta W. Kamdani said that in aggregate Indonesia's economic growth was still in a relatively solid range, conditions on the ground showed an uneven recovery. According to him, macro growth figures do not fully reflect the operational challenges faced by industry, especially manufacturing.

"So in general, I think there are still a lot of things, especially in the manufacturing industry, that are still experiencing a lot of slowdown," said Shinta at the Kempinski Hotel Jakarta, Tuesday (10/2/2026).

This can be seen from the performance of a number of strategic subsectors which grew lower than the national average, some even experiencing contraction. The performance of several subsectors was recorded as relatively low. The textile industry only grew 3.55%, footwear 3.31%, paper 3.36% and furniture 1.60%. The metal goods, computers, electronic goods and electrical equipment industry also grew 4.58% or still below national growth.

On the other hand, the wood and rattan industry contracted -3.29%, tobacco processing -1.37%, transportation equipment 2.65%, and the rubber and plastic goods industry -4.07%.  "Isone numbers are like that, but we look more at the real conditions, how we operate in the field, and what kind of challenges we operate in the field," he said.

Shinta assesses that the challenge in 2026 is not only about maintaining the rate of economic growth, but ensuring that this growth is able to create structural strengthening in the real sector. He emphasized the importance of a strategy that focuses on improving the fundamentals of the business world.

One of the crucial issues that Apindo continues to highlight is the high cost of doing business in Indonesia. Logistics costs, energy and loan interest rates are considered to be far less competitive than neighboring countries, thereby suppressing the competitiveness of national industry. "The interest rate on our loans can be up to 8 to 12%, whereas in other countries it's only 4% to 6%. So this is a cost of doing business that we also need to pay attention to," he explained.

Apart from quantitative costs, Shinta also highlighted non-quantitative costs such as complicated licensing, overlapping regulations, and policy inconsistencies between the center and regions. According to Shinta, this condition also hampers investment, which has been the main motor of economic growth.

Bisnis.com, JAKARTA -- Transformasi ekonomi Indonesia berjalan pelan menyusul masih besarnya kontribusi sektor pertanian dalam struktur produk domestik bruto (PDB) Indonesia. Di sisi lain, kontribusi manufaktur ke PDB mentok di angka 19% dan selama 8 tahun terakhir, kontribusinya ke PDB tidak pernah kembali ke angka 20%. Selain itu produktivitas manufaktur-pun kini disorot Bank Dunia alias World Bank.

Bank Dunia dalam laporan terbarunya mengemukakan bahwa di balik guyuran investasi yang naik dalam waktu 5 tahun terakhir, mayoritas aliran modal tersebut mengalir deras ke sektor bernilai tambah rendah sehingga turut menjadi penyebab anjloknya produktivitas manufaktur nasional.

Berdasarkan dokumen Country Growth & Jobs Report: Indonesia yang dirilis akhir Januari 2026, Bank Dunia mengungkapkan tingkat investasi RI rata-rata mencapai 30% terhadap Produk Domestik Bruto (PDB) dalam 15 tahun terakhir. "Kendati demikian, sekitar 70% dari investasi ini mengalir ke sektor manufaktur bernilai-tambah rendah," tulis Bank Dunia dalam laporannya, dikutip Selasa (17/2/2026).

Lembaga yang bermarkas di Washington DC ini mencatat 70% realisasi investasi Indonesia tersedot ke industri makanan olahan, logam dasar, serta layanan akomodasi dan makanan akibat dorongan siklus komoditas.

Kondisi saat ini berbanding terbalik dengan aliran modal ke manufaktur berorientasi ekspor dan bernilai tinggi, seperti otomotif, elektronik, farmasi, dan teknologi informasi dan komunikasi (TIK). Padahal, Bank Dunia menjelaskan sektor-sektor tersebut menjadi primadona investasi pada awal hingga pertengahan 1990-an, yang didorong oleh reformasi perdagangan dan deregulasi.

Masalahnya, setelah itu, terjadi tren pembatasan pasar di Tanah Air. Akibatnya, menurut Bank Dunia, fenomena tersebut menjadi biang kerok anjloknya produktivitas manufaktur Indonesia sebesar 20% hingga 30% dibandingkan era kejayaannya di awal 1990-an.

Baca Juga

  • Banyak Catatan di Balik Rekor Pertumbuhan Sektor Manufaktur dan Pertanian
  • Tanpa Reformasi Biaya Produksi, Indef Sebut Manufaktur RI Sulit Tancap Gas
  • Apindo: 9 dari 16 Subsektor Manufaktur Tumbuh di Bawah Rerata Nasional

"Meningkatnya pembatasan pasar telah melindungi perusahaan-perusahaan terkemuka dan perusahaan milik negara dari persaingan, memusatkan aktivitas pada manufaktur dan jasa yang bernilai rendah," ungkap laporan tersebut.

Bank Dunia mengakui bahwa pemerintah Indonesia sebenarnya tidak tinggal diam melihat kemerosotan ini lewat pengesahan UU Cipta Kerja pada 2020 dan berbagai reformasi regulasi bisnis. Aturan sapu jagat itu dirancang untuk meliberalisasi sektor usaha dan melonggarkan batasan investasi asing langsung.

Langkah ini diakui memang berhasil memicu kenaikan komitmen investasi di sektor-sektor tersebut. Hanya saja, realisasi yang masuk ternyata ‘jauh panggang dari api’. "Aliran investasi aktual masih jauh dari harapan, sebagian besar disebabkan oleh berbagai tantangan implementasi [UU Cipta Kerja] di lapangan," jelas laporan tersebut.

Investasi dan Serapan Pekerja

Dalam catatan Bisnis, kualitas investasi terus menurun, setidaknya apabila dilihat dari sisi penyerapan tenaga kerja. Selama 2025, kenaikan investasi tidak sebanding dengan kenaikan penyerapan tenaga kerja.

Berdasarkan data Kementerian Investasi dan Hilirisasi/Badan Koordinasi Penanaman Modal (BKPM), realisasi investasi mencapai Rp1.931,2 triliun sepanjang 2025. Dari realisasi investasi itu, penyerapan tenaga kerjanya mencapai 2.710.532 orang.

Dengan demikian, setiap 1 tenaga kerja yang terserap memerlukan investasi sekitar Rp712,48 juta.

Apabila dibandingkan dengan periode yang sama tahun lalu atau sepanjang 2024, realisasi investasi 'hanya' mencapai Rp1.714,2 triliun (lebih rendah Rp217 triliun atau 12,66% dibandingkan realisasi tahun ini). Kendati demikian, penyerapan tenaga kerjanya mencapai 2.456.130 orang.

Dengan demikian, setiap 1 orang tenaga kerja terserap 'hanya' memerlukan investasi sekitar Rp698,1 juta (lebih 'murah' Rp13,8 juta).

Artinya, terjadi penurunan rasio penyerapan tenaga kerja terhadap realisasi investasi: serapan tenaga kerja malah memburuk ketika nilai investasi langsung tumbuh positif.

Transformasi Ekonomi Berjalan Lamban?

Sekadar catatan, industri pengolahan dan pertanian sejatinya mengalami pertumbuhan yang cukup impresif pada tahun 2025. Kedua sektor itu mencatat rekor pertumbuhan tertinggi sejak 2015 lalu yakni di atas 5%. 

Sektor manufaktur atau industri pengolahan secara keseluruhan tumbuh 5,3% (YoY) sepanjang 2025, lebih tinggi dibandingkan tahun 2024 yakni 4,43%. Sementara itu, sektor pertanian pertumbuhannya sangat eksponensial menembus angka 5,3%. Selain di atas realisasi pertumbuhan ekonomi, angka itu melesat dari tahun 2024 yang hanya 0,6%. 

"Jika dilihat dari kontribusi pertumbuhan ekonomi secara kumulatif pada 2025, dari sisi lapangan usaha, industri pengolahan menjadi sumber pertumbuhan tertinggi sebesar 1,07%. Angka ini merupakan yang tertinggi selama empat tahun terakhir," ucap Kepala BPS Amalia Adininggar Widyasanti pada konferensi pers, Kamis (5/2/2026).

Meski mencatat rekor pertumbuhan tertinggi, kinerja kedua sektor itu bukannya tanpa catatan. Sektor manufaktur, misalnya, tumbuh ketika impor bahan baku turun dan sektor padat karya mengalami tekanan.

Adapun tekanan di sektor padat karya tampak dari tingginya angka pemutusan hubungan kerja dan semakin tidak efektifnya investasi dalam menyerap tenaga kerja. Kontribusi sektor manufaktur-pun tidak pernah bisa menyentuh angka 20%, setidaknya sejak 2018.

Sementara itu, sektor pertanian yang sepanjang tahun lalu tumbuh 5,33% (YoY), juga telah menjadi sumber pertumbuhan ekonomi. Angkanya bahkan tertinggi dalam empat tahun yakni 0,60%. Sumber pertumbuhan itu sudah melebihi level 2022 yang saat itu masih 0,29%.

Namun demikian, tingginya pertumbuhan dan kontribusi sektor pertanian ke PDB, tidak selamanya menjadi kabar yang menggembirakan bagi perekonomian. Pasalnya, hal itu juga bisa dimaknai sebagai tanda-tanda terjadinya stagnasi dalam proses transformasi ekonomi Indonesia dari masyarakat agraris ke arah industrialisasi.

Struktur Tidak Berubah

Direktur Eksekutif Institute for Development of Economics and Finance (Indef) Esther Sri Astuti memandang sejatinya tidak ada yang berubah pada struktur perekonomian Indonesia, lantaran pertanian memang konsisten menjadi kontributor besar terhadap perekonomian Indonesia. Bedanya, industri manufaktur diakui tengah mengalami degradasi. 

"Dari dulu sektor pertanian juga masih berkontribusi besar, dan industri manufaktur yang mengalami degradasi gitu," terangnya kepada Bisnis, Senin (16/2/2026). 

Secara terperinci, Esther melihat bahwa pertumbuhan yang tinggi pada sektor manufaktur tidak mencerminkan pertumbuhan pada sektor padat karya. Di lapangan, sektor yang bersifat labor intensive atau menciptakan lapangan kerja besar itu diakui justru masih mengalami kesulitan. 

Salah satunya adalah sektor tekstil. Esther melihat tantangan yang dialami sektor tekstil datang dari berbagai sisi, mulai dari mahalnya bahan baku hingga gempuran baju asal impor.  "Di pasar domestik pun itu kan kita dapat serangan ya dari kumpulan produk-produk kayak China, gitu kan, which is yang jauh lebih murah harganya dan lebih bagus juga kualitasnya. Nah itu memang strateginya China, ya," kata Esther kepada Bisnis, Senin (16/2/2026). 

Tidak hanya akibat serangan baju impor, Esther turut menyoroti masalah fundamental pada sektor tekstil. Dari segi investasi, dosen Fakultas Ekonomika dan Bisnis Universitas Diponegoro (FEB Undip) itu juga menilai pemerintah perlu mendatangkan lebih banyak investor di sektor tekstil agar terciptanya ekosistem dari hulu hingga ke hilir.

Menurutnya, sebagian pengusaha sudah memiliki alat produksi yang canggih. Namun, kualitasnya masih kalah saing dengan industri luar negeri apabila dilihat dari sisi pengembangan SDM. 

"Masalah model, fashion, style, kita tuh sekolah tekstil kan sangat kurang. Sementara kalau di US, itu dari sekolah tekstil, itu dari SMK sampai universitas sudah lengkap, sudah ada. Nah kita kan cuma ada sekolah tekstil. Fundamental problem-nya harus dibenerin, kalau ingin bikin tekstil kita survive dan kembali jaya seperti tahun 90-an," terangnya.

Catatan dari Pengusaha 

Asosiasi Pengusaha Indonesia (Apindo) menyebut 9 dari 16 subsektor manufaktur masih tumbuh di bawah rata-rata nasional sepanjang 2025. Kondisi tersebut mencerminkan tekanan nyata yang masih dirasakan pelaku usaha di sektor riil.

Ketua Umum Apindo Shinta W. Kamdani mengatakan secara agregat pertumbuhan ekonomi Indonesia masih berada di kisaran yang relatif solid, kondisi di lapangan menunjukkan pemulihan yang tidak merata. Menurutnya, angka pertumbuhan makro belum sepenuhnya merefleksikan tantangan operasional yang dihadapi industri, khususnya manufaktur.

“Jadi in general saya rasa banyak sekali masih, terutama di industri manufaktur masih mengalami banyak perlambatan,” kata Shinta di Hotel Kempinski Jakarta, Selasa (10/2/2026).

Hal ini terlihat dari kinerja sejumlah subsektor strategis yang tumbuh lebih rendah dibandingkan rata-rata nasional, bahkan ada yang mengalami kontraksi. Kinerja beberapa subsektor tercatat relatif rendah. Industri tekstil hanya tumbuh 3,55%, alas kaki 3,31%, kertas 3,36% dan furnitur 1,60%. Industri barang logam, komputer, barang elektronik dan peralatan listrik juga tumbuh 4,58% atau masih di bawah pertumbuhan nasional. 

Di sisi lain, industri kayu dan rotan kontraksi -3,29%, pengolahan tembakau -1,37%, alat angkutan 2,65%, dan industri karet serta barang plastik -4,07%.  "Angka is one thing gitu, tapi kita lebih melihat kondisi riil itu bagaimana kita beroperasi di lapangan, dan tantangan-tantangannya seperti apa kita beroperasi di lapangan," tuturnya. 

Shinta menilai tantangan pada 2026 tidak hanya soal menjaga laju pertumbuhan ekonomi, tetapi memastikan pertumbuhan tersebut mampu menciptakan penguatan struktural di sektor riil. Dia menekankan pentingnya strategi yang berfokus pada perbaikan fundamental dunia usaha.

Salah satu isu krusial yang terus disoroti Apindo adalah tingginya biaya berusaha (high cost of doing business) di Indonesia. Biaya logistik, energi, hingga suku bunga pinjaman dinilai masih jauh kurang kompetitif dibanding negara-negara tetangga, sehingga menekan daya saing industri nasional. “Suku bunga pinjaman kita itu bisa sampai 8 sampai 12%, kalau negara lain cuma 4% sampai 6%-an. Jadi ini menjadi cost of doing business yang harus menjadi perhatian kita juga," jelasnya.

Selain biaya yang bersifat kuantitatif, Shinta juga menyoroti beban non-kuantitatif seperti perizinan yang berbelit, regulasi yang tumpang tindih, serta inkonsistensi kebijakan antara pusat dan daerah. Menurut Shinta, kondisi tersebut turut menghambat investasi, yang selama ini menjadi motor utama pertumbuhan ekonomi.

Selain itu produktivitas manufaktur-pun kini disorot Bank Dunia aliasWorld Bank.

Bank Dunia dalam laporan terbarunya mengemukakan bahwa di balik guyuran investasi yang naik dalam waktu 5 tahun terakhir, mayoritas aliran modal tersebut mengalir deras ke sektor bernilai tambah rendah sehingga turut menjadi penyebab anjloknya produktivitas manufaktur nasional.

Berdasarkan dokumenCountry Growth & Jobs Report: Indonesiayang dirilis akhir Januari 2026, Bank Dunia mengungkapkan tingkat investasi RI rata-rata mencapai 30% terhadap Produk Domestik Bruto (PDB) dalam 15 tahun terakhir. "Kendati demikian, sekitar 70% dari investasi ini mengalir ke sektor manufaktur bernilai-tambah rendah," tulis Bank Dunia dalam laporannya, dikutip Selasa (17/2/2026).

Lembaga yang bermarkas di Washington DC ini mencatat 70% realisasi investasi Indonesia tersedot ke industri makanan olahan, logam dasar, serta layanan akomodasi dan makanan akibat dorongan siklus komoditas.

Kondisi saat ini berbanding terbalik dengan aliran modal ke manufaktur berorientasi ekspor dan bernilai tinggi, seperti otomotif, elektronik, farmasi, dan teknologi informasi dan komunikasi (TIK). Padahal, Bank Dunia menjelaskan sektor-sektor tersebut menjadi primadona investasi pada awal hingga pertengahan 1990-an, yang didorong oleh reformasi perdagangan dan deregulasi.

Masalahnya, setelah itu, terjadi tren pembatasan pasar di Tanah Air. Akibatnya, menurut Bank Dunia, fenomena tersebut menjadi biang kerok anjloknya produktivitas manufaktur Indonesia sebesar 20% hingga 30% dibandingkan era kejayaannya di awal 1990-an.

"Meningkatnya pembatasan pasar telah melindungi perusahaan-perusahaan terkemuka dan perusahaan milik negara dari persaingan, memusatkan aktivitas pada manufaktur dan jasa yang bernilai rendah," ungkap laporan tersebut.

Bank Dunia mengakui bahwa pemerintah Indonesia sebenarnya tidak tinggal diam melihat kemerosotan ini lewat pengesahan UU Cipta Kerja pada 2020 dan berbagai reformasi regulasi bisnis. Aturan sapu jagat itu dirancang untuk meliberalisasi sektor usaha dan melonggarkan batasan investasi asing langsung.

Langkah ini diakui memang berhasil memicu kenaikan komitmen investasi di sektor-sektor tersebut. Hanya saja, realisasi yang masuk ternyata ‘jauh panggang dari api’. "Aliran investasi aktual masih jauh dari harapan, sebagian besar disebabkan oleh berbagai tantangan implementasi [UU Cipta Kerja] di lapangan," jelas laporan tersebut.

Dalam catatanBisnis, kualitas investasi terus menurun, setidaknya apabila dilihat dari sisi penyerapan tenaga kerja. Selama 2025, kenaikan investasi tidak sebanding dengan kenaikan penyerapan tenaga kerja.

Berdasarkan data Kementerian Investasi dan Hilirisasi/Badan Koordinasi Penanaman Modal (BKPM), realisasi investasi mencapai Rp1.931,2 triliun sepanjang 2025. Dari realisasi investasi itu, penyerapan tenaga kerjanya mencapai 2.710.532 orang.

Dengan demikian, setiap 1 tenaga kerja yang terserap memerlukan investasi sekitar Rp712,48 juta.

Apabila dibandingkan dengan periode yang sama tahun lalu atau sepanjang 2024, realisasi investasi 'hanya' mencapai Rp1.714,2 triliun (lebih rendah Rp217 triliun atau 12,66% dibandingkan realisasi tahun ini). Kendati demikian, penyerapan tenaga kerjanya mencapai 2.456.130 orang.

Dengan demikian, setiap 1 orang tenaga kerja terserap 'hanya' memerlukan investasi sekitar Rp698,1 juta (lebih 'murah' Rp13,8 juta).

title: Spinning Industry Utilization Drops, US Cotton Purchases Threatened to Slug
content:
Bisnis.com, JAKARTA — The plan to increase cotton purchases from the United States (US) is considered difficult to realize amidst the low utilization of the domestic spinning industry. This condition means that demand for raw materials has not been able to recover to what it was before the pandemic.

In fact, the plan to increase cotton purchases from the US is part of the negotiation steps to reduce trade tariffs to 19% for products from Indonesia.

Chairman of the Indonesian Fiber and Filament Yarn Producers Association (APSyFI), Redma G. Wirawasta, said that the pressure on the upstream textile industry was still very heavy. Weakening domestic market demand and the invasion of imported products means production capacity is not optimal.

"The US asked us to buy more cotton from them. This will be difficult to implement as long as our spinning industry's utilization is still below 50%," said Redma to Bisnis, Wednesday (18/2/2026).

Before the pandemic, Indonesia's total cotton imports reached around 600,000 tons per year. Of this amount, around 300,000 tonnes came from the US, making Uncle Sam's country one of the main suppliers of raw materials for the national textile industry.

However, since 2022 the import trend has continued to decline. Until 2025, Indonesia's total cotton imports will only be around 300,000 tons, with the share from the US shrinking drastically to around 70,000 tons.

Also Read

Redma emphasized that as long as the utilization rate does not improve, increasing imports is almost impossible.

"So as long as the utilization of the spinning industry is below 50%, it is unlikely that our cotton imports from the US will increase," he stressed.

According to him, low utilization is not without reason. The spinning industry is facing pressure from the flood of imported products, both in the form of cloth and yarn, which are sold at very competitive prices, and are even suspected of being dumped.

This condition means that the domestic market, which should be the main support, is actually being eroded by foreign products. Without a healthy market and fair competition, domestic industry has difficulty increasing production.

"Of course we hope that the US will provide tariff relief so that our exports to the US can become competitive again, even though this will be difficult without improvements on the industrial side," he concluded.

Bisnis.com, JAKARTA — Rencana peningkatan pembelian kapas (cotton) dari Amerika Serikat (AS) dinilai sulit direalisasikan di tengah rendahnya utilisasi industri pemintalan dalam negeri. Kondisi ini membuat permintaan bahan baku belum mampu pulih seperti sebelum pandemi.

Padahal, rencana peningkatan pembelian kapas dari AS merupakan bagian dari langkah negosiasi penurunan tarif dagang menjadi 19% untuk produk asal Indonesia.

Ketua Umum Asosiasi Produsen Serat dan Benang Filamen Indonesia (APSyFI), Redma G. Wirawasta, mengatakan bahwa tekanan pada industri hulu tekstil masih sangat berat. Permintaan pasar domestik yang melemah dan serbuan produk impor membuat kapasitas produksi tidak optimal.

“AS meminta kita membeli lebih banyak cotton dari mereka. Hal ini akan sulit dilaksanakan selama industri pemintalan kita utilisasinya masih di bawah 50%,” ujar Redma kepada Bisnis, Rabu (18/2/2026).

Sebelum pandemi, total impor kapas Indonesia mencapai sekitar 600.000 ton per tahun. Dari jumlah tersebut, sekitar 300.000 ton berasal dari AS, menjadikan Negeri Paman Sam sebagai salah satu pemasok utama bahan baku industri tekstil nasional.

Namun, sejak 2022 tren impor terus mengalami penurunan. Hingga 2025, total impor kapas Indonesia hanya sekitar 300.000 ton, dengan porsi dari AS menyusut drastis menjadi sekitar 70.000 ton.

Redma menegaskan, selama tingkat utilisasi belum membaik, peningkatan impor hampir mustahil terjadi.

“Jadi selama utilisasi industri pemintalan berada di bawah 50%, kecil kemungkinan impor cotton kita dari AS bisa naik,” tegasnya.

Menurutnya, rendahnya utilisasi bukan tanpa sebab. Industri pemintalan menghadapi tekanan dari membanjirnya produk impor, baik berupa kain maupun benang, yang dijual dengan harga sangat kompetitif, bahkan diduga dilakukan secara dumping.

Kondisi tersebut membuat pasar domestik yang seharusnya menjadi penopang utama justru tergerus oleh produk luar negeri. Tanpa pasar yang sehat dan persaingan yang adil, industri dalam negeri kesulitan meningkatkan produksi.

“Tentunya kami berharap AS akan memberikan keringanan tarif agar ekspor kita ke AS bisa kembali bersaing, meskipun hal itu sulit tanpa ada perbaikan di sisi industrinya,” tutupnya.

Sebelum pandemi, total impor kapas Indonesia mencapai sekitar 600.000 ton per tahun. Dari jumlah tersebut, sekitar 300.000 ton berasal dari AS, menjadikan Negeri Paman Sam sebagai salah satu pemasok utama bahan baku industri tekstil nasional.

Namun, sejak 2022 tren impor terus mengalami penurunan. Hingga 2025, total impor kapas Indonesia hanya sekitar 300.000 ton, dengan porsi dari AS menyusut drastis menjadi sekitar 70.000 ton.

Baca Juga

Redma menegaskan, selama tingkat utilisasi belum membaik, peningkatan impor hampir mustahil terjadi.

“Jadi selama utilisasi industri pemintalan berada di bawah 50%, kecil kemungkinan impor cotton kita dari AS bisa naik,” tegasnya.

Menurutnya, rendahnya utilisasi bukan tanpa sebab. Industri pemintalan menghadapi tekanan dari membanjirnya produk impor, baik berupa kain maupun benang, yang dijual dengan harga sangat kompetitif, bahkan diduga dilakukan secara dumping.

Kondisi tersebut membuat pasar domestik yang seharusnya menjadi penopang utama justru tergerus oleh produk luar negeri. Tanpa pasar yang sehat dan persaingan yang adil, industri dalam negeri kesulitan meningkatkan produksi.

“Tentunya kami berharap AS akan memberikan keringanan tarif agar ekspor kita ke AS bisa kembali bersaing, meskipun hal itu sulit tanpa ada perbaikan di sisi industrinya,” tutupnya.

title: Food Prices Today February 18: Rice Prices Drop, Beef Soars
content:
Bisnis.com, JAKARTA —National average food prices in Indonesia tend to vary today, Wednesday (18/2/2026), the day after the Chinese New Year celebration and one day before Ramadan 2026.

Based on the National Food Agency (Bapanas) price panel page at 09.50 WIB, the average price of premium rice in the country fell 1.6% to IDR 15,405 per kilogram compared to the previous day.

The price of medium rice also fell 1.14% to IDR 13,237 per kilogram, while Perum Bulog's Food Supply and Price Stabilization (SPHP) rice fell 0.35% to IDR 12,400 per kilogram.

Apart from that, there was also the price of non-SPHP medium rice which fell 0.58% to IDR 13,847 per kilogram, as well as local special rice which rose 1.45% to IDR 15,992.

Other commodities such as livestock corn fell 5.87% to IDR 6,555 per kilogram, and imported dry seed soybeans fell 0.82% to IDR 10,839 per kilogram.

Meanwhile, red onions fell 4.12% to IDR 40,367 per kilogram, while bulb garlic was also 2.35% cheaper to IDR 38,351 per kilogram.

Also Read

Meanwhile, curly red chilies fell 2.88% to IDR 44,564 per kilogram, large red chilies fell 8.41% to IDR 38,789 per kilogram, while red cayenne peppers fell 0.25% to IDR 75,582 per kilogram.

On the other hand, the price of pure beef rose 1.26% to IDR 141,332 per kilogram. The price of purebred chicken meat fell 1.14% to IDR 41,022 per kilogram, while purebred chicken eggs fell 1.86% to IDR 30,672 per kilogram.

Furthermore, the price of consumer sugar was observed to fall 0.92% to IDR 18,120 per kilogram, consumption salt fell 1.64% to IDR 11,441 per kilogram, bulk wheat flour fell 2.62% to IDR 9,524 and packaged wheat flour fell 3.33% to IDR 12,636.

The price of packaged cooking oil was observed to fall 1.72% to IDR 20,875 per liter, while bulk cooking oil fell 0.46% to IDR 17,646 per liter. Meanwhile, Minyakita fell 1.62% to IDR 16,903 per liter.

Meanwhile, the price of mackerel rose 3.68% to IDR 47,377 per kilogram, mackerel rose 0.01% to IDR 37,614 per kilogram, while milkfish rose 0.90% to IDR 37,534 per kilogram.

Price changes also occurred for foreign imported frozen buffalo meat, which fell 2.93% to IDR 110,392 per kilogram. Meanwhile, local fresh buffalo meat rose 1.46% to IDR 152,667 per kilogram.

title: Central Java Phase II People's School Construction Begins, Here's the Location Distribution
content:
Bisnis.com, JAKARTA — The Ministry of Public Works (PU) has officially started the physical construction of Phase II People's Schools in Central Java Province. This educational infrastructure project is spread across 11 locations whose implementation areas are categorized into two clusters, namely Central Java 1 and Central Java 2.

PU Minister Dody Hanggodo explained that Central Java region 1 includes development in Banyumas, Cilacap, Brebes, Wonosobo and Temanggung regencies.

Meanwhile, the Central Java 2 region includes six points located in Jepara, Pati, Rembang, Sragen, Sukoharjo, and Semarang City.

"The Ministry of Public Works ensures that the People's School educational facilities are built quickly, precisely and with quality so that the community can immediately use them," said Dody in an official statement, Wednesday (18/2/2026).

Regarding technical implementation, Dody highlighted construction access obstacles in Brebes Regency, which is located close to the Pemali River and Jalan Raya Brebes. In line with this, the government is currently reviewing plans to build an emergency bridge (Bailey) to mobilize building materials to the school site so that the completion target is not hampered.

Meanwhile, initial work in Brebes is now just entering the land striping and heavy equipment mobilization stage. Where, the continuation of the physical construction of the building is still waiting for the final decision regarding the provision of emergency bridge access as the main logistics route for the project.

Also Read

Meanwhile, based on physical progress data in the 11th week or the period 2–8 February 2026, the realization of the construction of People's Schools in the Central Java 1 region has only reached 2.717%.

For the Central Java 2 region, progress was recorded slightly higher at 6.337%, with the highest achievement being in Temanggung Regency which reached 30.05%.

"Phase II People's School will be built permanently on 5-10 hectares of land prepared by the regional government," added Dody.

For information, nationally the Phase II People's School project covers 104 locations in 32 provinces and 102 districts/cities.

This program targets a total capacity of 112,320 students divided into 3,744 study groups to support equal distribution of the quality of human resources in Indonesia.

Bisnis.com, JAKARTA — Kementerian Pekerjaan Umum (PU) resmi memulai pembangunan fisik Sekolah Rakyat Tahap II di Provinsi Jawa Tengah. Proyek infrastruktur pendidikan ini tersebar di 11 lokasi yang pembagian wilayah pelaksanaannya dikategorikan ke dalam dua klaster, yakni Jawa Tengah 1 dan Jawa Tengah 2.

Menteri PU Dody Hanggodo menjelaskan, wilayah Jawa Tengah 1 mencakup pembangunan di Kabupaten Banyumas, Cilacap, Brebes, Wonosobo, dan Temanggung.

Sementara itu, untuk wilayah Jawa Tengah 2 meliputi enam titik yang berlokasi di Kabupaten Jepara, Pati, Rembang, Sragen, Sukoharjo, serta Kota Semarang.

“Kementerian PU memastikan fasilitas pendidikan Sekolah Rakyat dibangun secara cepat, tepat, dan berkualitas agar segera dimanfaatkan masyarakat,” kata Dody dalam keterangan resmi, Rabu (18/2/2026).

Terkait teknis pelaksanaan, Dody menyoroti kendala akses konstruksi di Kabupaten Brebes yang lokasinya berdekatan dengan Sungai Pemali dan Jalan Raya Brebes. Sejalan dengan hal itu, saat ini pemerintah tengah mengkaji rencana pembangunan jembatan darurat (Bailey) guna memobilisasi material bangunan ke lokasi sekolah agar target penyelesaian tidak terhambat.

Sementara itu, pekerjaan awal di Brebes kini baru memasuki tahap striping lahan dan mobilisasi alat berat. Di mana, kelanjutan konstruksi fisik bangunan masih menunggu keputusan final terkait penyediaan akses jembatan darurat sebagai jalur logistik utama proyek tersebut.

Untuk wilayah Jawa Tengah 2, progres tercatat sedikit lebih tinggi di angka 6,337%, dengan capaian tertinggi berada di Kabupaten Temanggung yang menyentuh 30,05%.

"Sekolah Rakyat Tahap II dibangun permanen di atas lahan seluas 5–10 hektare yang disiapkan pemerintah daerah," tambah Dody.

Sebagai informasi, secara nasional proyek Sekolah Rakyat Tahap II mencakup 104 lokasi di 32 provinsi dan 102 kabupaten/kota. 

Program ini menargetkan total daya tampung sebanyak 112.320 siswa yang terbagi dalam 3.744 rombongan belajar guna mendukung pemerataan kualitas sumber daya manusia di Indonesia.

title: A series of important notes ahead of the finalization of RI-US trade tariffs
content:
Bisnis.com, JAKARTA — Negotiations on a trade agreement between Indonesia and the United States (US) will soon enter a new phase as a meeting will be held between President Prabowo Subianto and President Donald Trump on February 19 2026.

A number of businessmen also conveyed a series of important notes that the government needed to pay attention to before the signing of the trade agreement with the US. This is because the latest US tariff policy towards Indonesia in the future will have an impact on the industrial sector in the country.

The Association of Fiber and Filament Yarn Producers (APSyFI) still hopes that the government will be able to negotiate lower tariffs with the US.

The textile and textile products (TPT) industry hopes that the reciprocal tariff, which is currently at the level of 19%, can be pushed lower so that the competitiveness of exports to Uncle Sam's country can recover.

APSyFI General Chair Redma Gita Wirawasta said that the United States market is still one of the main destinations for Indonesian textile exports. However, the tariff burden is considered to make it difficult for national products to compete with other countries that receive more competitive treatment.

"Of course we hope that the US will provide tariff relief so that our exports to the US can become competitive again, even though this is difficult without improvements on the industrial side," said Redma to Bisnis, Tuesday (17/2/2026).

Also Read

In these negotiations, the US is said to have asked Indonesia to increase cotton purchases from Uncle Sam's country as one of the conditions for reducing reciprocal tariffs from the previous 32% to 19%. This demand is a challenge in itself amidst conditions in the spinning industry that have not yet fully recovered.

According to Redma, increasing cotton imports from the US is difficult to realize if the spinning industry utilization rate is still below 50%. With production capacity not yet optimal, the need for raw materials automatically decreases.

"This will be difficult to implement as long as our spinning industry's utilization is still below 50%," he explained.

APSyFI data notes that before the Covid-19 pandemic, Indonesia's total cotton imports reached around 600,000 tons per year, with around 300,000 tons coming from the United States. However, since 2022 the import trend has continued to decline significantly.

In 2025, Indonesia's total cotton imports will be recorded at only around 300,000 tons, with the portion from the United States remaining at around 70,000 tons. This decline reflects sluggish production activity in the spinning sector in recent years.

"So as long as the utilization of the spinning industry is below 50%, it is unlikely that our cotton imports from the US will increase," he explained.

He added that the low utilization of industry cannot be separated from the flood of imported products which are suspected of being sold through dumping practices, both in the form of cloth and thread. This condition puts pressure on the domestic market and erodes demand for domestic products.

"It is impossible for spinning utilization to increase as long as dumped imported goods, both cloth and yarn, continue to flood the domestic market. Because the industry's main need is the market and fair competition," he said.

The Indonesian Employers' Association (Apindo) asked the government to make labor-intensive industries a priority for protection in US tariff negotiations. This message was delivered ahead of the finalization of the trade agreement between Prabowo and Trump.

General Chairperson of Apindo Shinta Widjaja Kamdani said the sectors most vulnerable to US tariff policies are labor-intensive industries that have high exposure to Uncle Sam's export market.

"Regarding US tariff policy, from the perspective of the business world, the most vulnerable sectors are labor-intensive industries which have high exposure to the export market to the United States," said Shinta to Bisnis, Monday (16/2/2026).

Based on export data, Shinta explained a number of commodities with significant dependence on the US market. He gave the example that knitted clothing and accessories account for around 61% of exports to the US, furniture and ambient lighting 59%, processed meat/fish/crustaceans around 56%, and leather products around 56%. Meanwhile, non-knitted clothing is around 49%, toys and sports equipment is around 45%, and footwear is around 33%.

According to him, the data shows that changes in tariffs will have a direct impact on orders, production capacity utilization levels, and company cash flow, which ultimately has the potential to reduce labor absorption.

"Therefore, these sectors [labor-intensive industries] need to be a priority for protection in negotiations, considering their contribution to manufacturing and national employment stability," he explained.

On the other hand, Shinta said that Apindo was involved in US reciprocal tariff negotiations by providing industry input, mapping business obstacles, and communicating with business world partners in the US.

Apart from that, Shinta assessed that strengthening Indonesia's bargaining position also requires an understanding of the context of US reciprocal tariff policy which aims to balance the trade balance and reduce the trade deficit.

"Indonesia's approach cannot only be defensive in asking for tariff reductions, but must also offer concrete solutions that answer these interests," he explained.

Based on the upload from the official Instagram account @sekretariat.kabinet, President Prabowo summoned Coordinating Minister for Economic Affairs Airlangga Hartarto, Minister of Finance Purbaya Yudhi Sadewa, Minister of State Secretary Prasetyo Hadi, and Minister of Investment and Downstreaming/Head of BKPM and CEO of Danantara Rosan Roeslani.

The meeting was held at his private residence in Hambalang, Bogor, on Sunday (15/2/2026). During the meeting, the Indonesian Head of State emphasized the importance of ensuring that Indonesia's position in every international economic negotiation is at the most favorable point for national interests, especially regarding tariff negotiations with the US.

"President Prabowo wants every policy taken to provide concrete benefits as soon as possible and as much as possible for Indonesia," he was quoted as saying on the official Instagram account @sekretariat.kabinet, Monday (16/2/2026).

Meanwhile, CSIS researcher Yoshe Rizal Damuri said US tariff pressure could weaken the competitiveness of national products amidst tight global market competition, especially in key markets such as the US and the European Union.

According to Yoshe, risks to the supply chain and dependence on imported commodities have also increased along with the protectionist policies adopted by a number of countries. He believes that this condition requires industry players to read market dynamics and the direction of global trade policy more carefully.

"Our competitors are not always cheaper, but they can benefit from preferential tariffs and clear trade rules," said Yoshe to Bisnis, quoted Tuesday (17/2/2026).

He explained that countries like Vietnam do not necessarily have lower production costs than Indonesia. However, Vietnam's advantage lies in market access through trade agreements that provide more competitive tariffs and regulatory certainty. In the context of the European Union market, for example, Vietnam has previously enjoyed 0% tariffs through a free trade agreement.

Meanwhile, Indonesia is still facing higher tariffs so its competitive position is relatively lagging behind. "In the current situation, it is increasingly important for us to diversify the market," he said.

Yoshe emphasized that heavy dependence on one market, such as the US, makes national industries more vulnerable when policy changes such as reciprocal tariffs occur. Diversification is considered to be an important strategy to maintain export stability.

Apart from tariffs, he also highlighted the trend of increasingly stringent sustainability regulations in various export destination countries. The Indonesian footwear industry needs to prepare to face demands for higher environmental standards and supply chain traceability.

“We also need to be prepared to face stricter sustainability regulations and chain traceability demands I supply," he said.

Meanwhile, the government implied that there would be 'surprises' related to the signing of a trade agreement or agreement on reciprocal trade (ART) between Indonesia and the United States (US).

Just for the record, the Indonesian and US governments have completed the entire negotiation process and legal language harmonization process (legal drafting) related to the trade agreement which began with the imposition of import tariffs on Indonesian products in 2025.

From initially being threatened with a 32% tariff, President Prabowo Subianto last year agreed with President Donald Trump to reduce import duties on Indonesian products to 19%. In contrast, most US products will be subject to 0% import duties.

Ahead of the signing of the trade agreement on February 19 2026, the entire results of the negotiations and preparation of the legal documents for the trade agreement have been submitted to President Prabowo. Coordinating Minister for the Economy Airlangga Hartarto, who led the team of negotiators, also presented the results the day before Prabowo left for the US.

"The presence of economic ministers in Hambalang [Prabowo's private residence] before the President's departure is a form of final consolidation so that Indonesia's position is solid in the negotiations. "We hope that there will be positive surprises from ART that will increasingly benefit Indonesia," said Coordinating Ministry for Economic Affairs spokesperson Haryo Limanseto in a press release, Monday (16/2/2026).

Haryo then said that tariff negotiations had been completed and the two countries had completed the process of harmonizing legal language or legal drafting.

In addition to reducing tariffs to 19%, the US government also excluded tariffs for a number of Indonesia's leading export commodities, including crude palm oil (CPO), coffee and cocoa.

Bisnis.com, JAKARTA — Negosasi kesepakatan dagang antara Indonesia dan Amerika Serikat (AS) bakal segera memasuki babak baru seiring dengan bakal digelarnya pertemuan antara Presiden Prabowo Subianto dan Presiden Donald Trump pada 19 Februari 2026.

Sejumlah pengusaha pun menyampaikan sederet catatan penting yang perlu diperhatikan pemerintah menjelang ditekennya kesepakatan dagang dengan AS. Pasalnya, kebijakan terbaru tarif AS terhadap Indonesia ke depannya bakal berdampak pada sektor industri di Tanah Air.

Asosiasi Produsen Serat dan Benang Filamen (APSyFI) masih menaruh harapan agar pemerintah mampu menegosiasikan tarif yang lebih rendah dengan AS.

Industri tekstil dan produk tekstil (TPT) berharap tarif resiprokal yang saat ini berada di level 19% bisa ditekan lebih rendah agar daya saing ekspor ke Negeri Paman Sam kembali pulih.

Ketua Umum APSyFI Redma Gita Wirawasta mengatakan, pasar Amerika Serikat masih menjadi salah satu tujuan utama ekspor tekstil Indonesia. Namun, beban tarif dinilai membuat produk nasional sulit bersaing dengan negara lain yang mendapatkan perlakuan lebih kompetitif.

“Tentunya kami berharap AS akan memberikan keringanan tarif agar ekspor kita ke AS bisa kembali bersaing meskipun hal itu sulit tanpa ada perbaikan di sisi industrinya,” ujar Redma kepada Bisnis, Selasa (17/2/2026). 

Baca Juga

  • Prabowo Bertemu Trump Rundingkan Tarif Bea Masuk, Apindo Minta Industri Padat Karya Dilindungi
  • Jelang Pertemuan Prabowo-Trump soal Tarif, Kadin Titip Ini Diprioritaskan
  • Prabowo Terbang ke AS Bahas Tarif, Isu Industrialisasi Nasional Harus Diutamakan

Dalam negosiasi tersebut, AS disebut meminta Indonesia meningkatkan pembelian kapas (cotton) dari Negeri Paman Sam sebagai salah satu syarat penurunan tarif resiprokal dari sebelumnya 32% menjadi 19%. Permintaan itu menjadi tantangan tersendiri di tengah kondisi industri pemintalan yang belum sepenuhnya pulih.

Menurut Redma, peningkatan impor kapas dari AS sulit direalisasikan apabila tingkat utilisasi industri pemintalan masih berada di bawah 50%. Dengan kapasitas produksi yang belum optimal, kebutuhan bahan baku otomatis ikut menurun.

“Hal ini akan sulit dilaksanakan selama industri pemintalan kita utilisasinya masih di bawah 50%,” terangnya.

Data APSyFI mencatat, sebelum pandemi Covid-19 total impor kapas Indonesia mencapai sekitar 600.000 ton per tahun, dengan sekitar 300.000 ton berasal dari Amerika Serikat. Namun, sejak 2022 tren impor terus mengalami penurunan signifikan.

Pada 2025, total impor kapas Indonesia tercatat hanya sekitar 300.000 ton, dengan porsi dari Amerika Serikat tinggal sekitar 70.000 ton. Penurunan ini mencerminkan lesunya aktivitas produksi di sektor pemintalan dalam beberapa tahun terakhir.

“Jadi selama utilisasi industri pemintalan berada di bawah 50%, kecil kemungkinan impor cotton kita dari AS bisa naik,” jelasnya.

Dia menambahkan, rendahnya utilisasi industri tidak lepas dari membanjirnya produk impor yang diduga dijual dengan praktik dumping, baik dalam bentuk kain maupun benang. Kondisi ini membuat pasar domestik tertekan dan menggerus permintaan terhadap produk dalam negeri.

“Utilisasi pemintalan tidak mungkin bisa naik selama barang-barang impor dumping baik kain maupun benang masih membanjiri pasar domestik. Karena kebutuhan utama industri hanyalah pasar dan persaingannya yang fair,” ujarnya.

Melindungi Industri Padat Karya

Asosiasi Pengusaha Indonesia (Apindo) meminta pemerintah menjadikan industri padat karya sebagai prioritas perlindungan dalam negosiasi tarif AS. Pesan ini disampaikan menjelang finalisasi kesepakatan dagang yang bakal oleh Prabowo dan Trump.

Ketua Umum Apindo Shinta Widjaja Kamdani mengatakan sektor paling rentan terhadap kebijakan tarif AS adalah industri padat karya yang memiliki eksposur tinggi ke pasar ekspor Negeri Paman Sam.

“Terkait kebijakan tarif AS, dari perspektif dunia usaha, sektor yang paling rentan adalah industri padat karya yang memiliki eksposur tinggi terhadap pasar ekspor ke Amerika Serikat,” kata Shinta kepada Bisnis, Senin (16/2/2026).

Berdasarkan data ekspor, Shinta memaparkan sejumlah komoditas dengan ketergantungan signifikan terhadap pasar AS. Dia mencontohkan, pakaian dan aksesori rajutan mencatat sekitar 61% ekspor ke AS, furnitur dan lampu sekitar 59%, olahan daging/ikan/krustasea sekitar 56%, serta produk kulit sekitar 56%. Adapun pakaian non-rajutan sekitar 49%, mainan dan perlengkapan olahraga sekitar 45%, dan alas kaki sekitar 33%.

Menurutnya, data tersebut menunjukkan perubahan tarif akan berdampak langsung pada pesanan, tingkat utilisasi kapasitas produksi, hingga arus kas perusahaan, yang pada akhirnya berpotensi menekan penyerapan tenaga kerja.

“Karena itu, sektor-sektor ini [industri padat karya] perlu menjadi prioritas perlindungan dalam negosiasi, mengingat kontribusinya terhadap manufaktur dan stabilitas ketenagakerjaan nasional,” terangnya.

Di sisi lain, Shinta menuturkan Apindo ikut terlibat dalam negosiasi tarif resiprokal AS dengan memberi masukan industri, memetakan hambatan usaha, hingga berkomunikasi dengan mitra dunia usaha di AS.

Posisi Tawar Indonesia

Selain itu, Shinta menilai penguatan posisi tawar Indonesia juga menuntut pemahaman atas konteks kebijakan tarif resiprokal AS yang bertujuan menyeimbangkan neraca perdagangan dan menekan defisit dagang.

“Pendekatan Indonesia tidak bisa hanya defensif meminta penurunan tarif, tetapi juga harus menawarkan solusi konkret yang menjawab kepentingan tersebut,” terangnya.

Berdasarkan unggahan akun Instagram resmi @sekretariat.kabinet, Presiden Prabowo memanggil Menteri Koordinator Bidang Perekonomian Airlangga Hartarto, Menteri Keuangan Purbaya Yudhi Sadewa, Menteri Sekretaris Negara Prasetyo Hadi, serta Menteri Investasi dan Hilirisasi/Kepala BKPM sekaligus CEO Danantara Rosan Roeslani.

Pertemuan itu dilaksanakan di kediaman pribadinya di Hambalang, Bogor, pada Minggu (15/2/2026). Dalam pertemuan tersebut, Kepala Negara RI menekankan pentingnya memastikan posisi Indonesia dalam setiap perundingan ekonomi internasional berada pada titik yang paling menguntungkan bagi kepentingan nasional, terutama terkait perundingan tarif dengan AS.

“Presiden Prabowo menginginkan setiap kebijakan yang diambil harus sesegera dan sebanyak mungkin memberi keuntungan konkret untuk Indonesia,” demikian dikutip dari akun Instagram resmi @sekretariat.kabinet, Senin (16/2/2026).

Daya Saing Industri

Sementara itu, Peneliti CSIS Yoshe Rizal Damuri mengatakan tekanan tarif AS dapat memperlemah daya saing produk nasional di tengah ketatnya persaingan pasar global, terutama di pasar utama seperti AS dan Uni Eropa.

Menurut Yoshe, risiko terhadap rantai pasok dan ketergantungan pada komoditas impor juga meningkat seiring kebijakan proteksionis yang ditempuh sejumlah negara. Dia menilai kondisi ini membuat pelaku industri harus lebih cermat membaca dinamika pasar dan arah kebijakan perdagangan global.

“Pesaing kita tidak selalu lebih murah, tetapi mereka bisa diuntungkan oleh tarif preferensial dan aturan perdagangan yang jelas,” ujar Yoshe kepada Bisnis, dikutip Selasa (17/2/2026).

Dia menjelaskan, negara seperti Vietnam memang belum tentu memiliki biaya produksi lebih rendah dari Indonesia. Namun, keunggulan Vietnam terletak pada akses pasar melalui perjanjian dagang yang memberikan tarif lebih kompetitif serta kepastian regulasi. Dalam konteks pasar Uni Eropa, misalnya, Vietnam telah lebih dulu menikmati tarif 0% melalui perjanjian dagang bebas.

Sementara itu, Indonesia masih menghadapi tarif yang lebih tinggi sehingga posisi kompetitifnya relatif tertinggal. “Dalam situasi saat ini, semakin penting bagi kita untuk melakukan diversifikasi pasar,” tuturnya.

Yoshe menekankan bahwa ketergantungan yang besar pada satu pasar, seperti AS, membuat industri nasional lebih rentan ketika terjadi perubahan kebijakan seperti tarif resiprokal. Diversifikasi dinilai menjadi strategi penting untuk menjaga stabilitas ekspor.

Selain soal tarif, ia juga menyoroti tren regulasi keberlanjutan yang semakin ketat di berbagai negara tujuan ekspor. Industri alas kaki Indonesia perlu bersiap menghadapi tuntutan standar lingkungan dan ketertelusuran rantai pasok yang lebih tinggi.

“Kita juga perlu bersiap menghadapi aturan keberlanjutan yang lebih ketat dan tuntutan ketertelusuran rantai pasok,” tuturnya.

Kejutan Pemerintah

Sementara itu, pemerintah menyiratkan bahwa akan ada 'kejutan' terkait dengan penandatanganan kesepakatan dagang atau agreement on reciprocal trade (ART) antara Indonesia dan Amerika Serikat (AS).

Sekadar catatan, pemerintah Indonesia dan AS telah menyelesaikan seluruh proses negosiasi dan proses harmonisasi bahasa hukum (legal drafting) terkait dengan perjanjian dagang yang diawali dengan pengenaan tarif impor terhadap produk Indonesia 2025 lalu.

Dari awalnya diancam dengan tarif 32%, Presiden Prabowo Subianto pada tahun lalu menyepakati dengan Presiden Donald Trump agar tarif bea masuk terhadap produk Indonesia diturunkan ke 19%. Sebaliknya, sebagian besar produk AS akan dikenai bea masuk 0%.

Menjelang penandatanganan kesepakatan dagang pada 19 Februari 2026, keseluruhan hasil negosiasi dan penyusunan dokumen hukum perjanjian dagang itu telah disampaikan kepada Presiden Prabowo. Menko Perekonomian Airlangga Hartarto, yang memimpin tim negosiator, turut menyampaikan hasil dimaksud sehari sebelum Prabowo bertolak ke AS.

"Hadirnya para menteri bidang ekonomi di Hambalang [kediaman pribadi Prabowo] sebelum keberangkatan Presiden merupakan bentuk konsolidasi akhir agar posisi Indonesia solid dalam perundingan. Kita berharap akan ada kejutan-kejutan positif dari ART yang semakin menguntungkan Indonesia," kata Juru Bicara Kemenko Perekonomian Haryo Limanseto melalui siaran pers, Senin (16/2/2026).

Haryo lalu menuturkan bahwa negosiasi tarif telah rampung dan kedua negara telah menyelesaikan proses harmonisasi bahasa hukum atau legal drafting.

Selain tarif turun menjadi 19%, pemerintah AS turut mengecualikan tarif bagi sejumlah komoditas unggulan ekspor Indonesia termasuk minyak kelapa sawit atau crude palm oil (CPO), kopi dan kakao.

title: Real Economy Weakening, Mobility Homecoming for Eid 2026 Estimated to Shrink
content:
Bisnis.com, JAKARTA — Observers view the erosion of people's real income as the main factor that has the potential to suppress mobility for returning home for Eid 2026. As a result, people are more selective in planning trips to their hometowns this year.

The Ministry of Transportation (Kemenhub) previously predicted a decrease in the number of people going home or traveling during Eid this year by -1.7% compared to the 2025 survey and -6.55% compared to last year's realization.

Chairman of the Institute for Transportation Studies and transportation observer Ki Darmaningtyas agrees with the survey results from the Ministry of Transportation. According to him, the decline occurred due to real economic conditions which were still sluggish.

"If there is a decline, I agree. I predict a decline because the economy is indeed sluggish," he said to Business, quoted on Wednesday (18/2/2026).

According to him, one of the groups affected is the State Civil Apparatus (ASN), which is a group that contributes to homecoming mobility, due to efficiency and restrictions on official travel.

"ASN now practically only comes from salaries and performance allowances, so they tend to be barely able to. Previously they had income from official travel, and that's what they saved to go home for Eid," he added.

Also Read

Apart from ASN, small business actors such as school canteen managers are also said to be affected by the decline in turnover due to the Free Nutritious Meal (MBG) program, so that the space to set aside savings for going home becomes more limited.

Likewise, Executive Director of the Center of Reform on Economics (Core) Indonesia, Mohammad Faisal, assessed that there are a number of factors that cause a potential decline in the number of homecoming travelers, including falling income.

This weakening is reflected in data from the Central Statistics Agency (BPS) for November 2025, which shows a decrease in real labor wages of -0.06% from the August 2025 period. A decrease of -5.29% also occurred in February 2025 compared to August 2024.

"So it continues to weaken in terms of people's real income and I think the lower middle class is experiencing it more. So this is also what I think is an important factor as to why there is a potential decline in people's mobility during Eid 2026," he said.

Moreover, continued Faisal, if some companies or employers pay in installments or are unable to provide THR as large as expected. This condition then affects homecoming plans.

This is in line with the purchasing power of the lower middle class, which according to Faisal is not very strong.

Even though there has been an increase in total demand and total expenditure in the last five months leading up to Christmas, it is estimated that it will continue until Eid, the retail sales index is still driven by spending from the upper middle class.

"So some of them are forced to choose to be more selective in shopping, including for going home. For going home, it's not just transportation costs that are calculated," continued Faisal.

Apart from that, Faisal views that people are increasingly selective in choosing when to return home because of Eid or holidays which are close to New Year or Chinese New Year.

These conditions show that economic factors, especially the weakening of real income and purchasing power, are the main determinants of the direction of people's mobility during the 2026 Eid homecoming - although the Minister of Transportation is optimistic that the realization of homecoming trips will be higher than predicted.

Bisnis.com, JAKARTA — Pengamat memandang tergerusnya pendapatan riil masyarakat menjadi faktor utama yang berpotensi menekan mobilitas mudik Lebaran 2026. Alhasil, masyarakat lebih selektif merencanakan perjalanan ke kampung halaman tahun ini. 

Kementerian Perhubungan (Kemenhub) sebelumnya memprediksi adanya penurunan jumlah masyarakat yang mudik atau melakukan mobilitas pada Lebaran tahun ini sebesar -1,7% terhadap survei 2025 dan -6,55% terhadap realisasi tahun lalu. 

Ketua Institut Studi Transportasi sekaligus pengamat transportasi Ki Darmaningtyas sepakat dengan hasil survei dari Kemenhub. Menurutnya, penurunan memang terjadi akibat kondisi ekonomi riil yang masih lesu. 

“Kalau terjadi penurunan saya sepakat. Saya prediksikan menurun karena ekonomi memang lesu,” ujarnya kepada Bisnis, dikutip pada Rabu (18/2/2026). 

Menurutnya, salah satu kelompok yang terdampak adalah pada Aparatur Sipil Negara (ASN), yang menjadi kelompok penyumbang mobilitas mudik, akibat efisiensi maupun pembatasan perjalanan dinas. 

“ASN sekarang praktis hanya dari gaji dan tunjangan kinerja saja sehingga cenderung pas-pasan. Sebelumnya mereka memiliki pendapatan dari perjalanan dinas, dan itulah yang mereka tabung untuk mudik lebaran,” tambahnya.

  • Prediksi Pemudik Lebaran 2026: 143,9 Juta Orang, Turun 1,7% Dibanding Tahun Lalu
  • AirAsia Diskon Tiket Pesawat Mudik Lebaran 2026, Cek Jadwal dan Rutenya
  • Angkutan Barang Dilarang Melintas saat Mudik Lebaran 2026, Berlaku 17 Hari

Selain ASN, pelaku usaha kecil seperti pengelola kantin sekolah juga disebut terdampak penurunan omzet akibat adanya program Makan Bergizi Gratis (MBG), sehingga ruang untuk menyisihkan tabungan mudik menjadi lebih terbatas.

Senada, Direktur Eksekutif Center of Reform on Economics (Core) Indonesia Mohammad Faisal menilai terdapat sejumlah faktor yang menyebabkan adanya potensi penurunan jumlah pemudik, termasuk pendapatan yang turun. 

Pelemahan tersebut tercermin dari data Badan Pusat Statistik (BPS) November 2025, yang menunjukkan adanya penurunan upah riil buruh sebesar -0,06% dari periode Agustus 2025. Penurunan sebesar -5,29% juga terjadi pada Februari 2025 dibandingkan Agustus 2024. 

“Jadi terus melemah sebetulnya dari sisi pendapatan riil masyarakat dan saya rasa yang lebih banyak mengalami itu kalangan menengah ke bawah. Jadi ini yang menyebabkan juga saya pikir faktor penting kenapa ada potensi penurunan mobilitas orang pada lebaran 2026,” katanya. 

Apalagi, lanjut Faisal, apabila sebagian perusahaan atau pemberi kerja yang menyicil ataupun tidak mampu memberikan THR sebesar yang diharapkan. Kondisi tersebut lantas berpengaruh terhadap rencana mudik. 

Hal tersebut sejalan dengan daya beli masyarakat kalangan menengah ke bawah yang menurut Faisal belum terlalu kuat. 

Meskipun dari total permintaan dan total pengeluaran ada peningkatan dalam lima bulan terakhir menjelang Nataru diperkirakan akan berlangsung terus sampai dengan lebaran, tetapi indeks penjualan ritel masih terdorong oleh belanja dari kalangan menengah atas. 

“Sehingga sebagian mereka terpaksa memilih untuk lebih selektif lagi dalam berbelanja, termasuk untuk keperluan mudik. Untuk mudik itu bukan hanya ongkos transportasi saja yang dihitung,” lanjut Faisal. 

Selain itu, Faisal memandang masyarakat semakin selektif memilih waktu pulang kampung karena posisi lebaran atau liburan yang berdekatan dengan tahun baru maupun Imlek. 

Kondisi tersebut menunjukkan bahwa faktor ekonomi, khususnya pelemahan pendapatan riil dan daya beli, menjadi penentu utama arah mobilitas masyarakat pada mudik Lebaran 2026—meski Menhub optimistis realisasi perjalanan pemudik akan lebih tinggi dari prediksi.

title: Tito: Sumatran Disaster Victims Get Housing Waiting Funds of IDR 1.8 Million per Family
content:
Bisnis.com, JAKARTA — The government through the Task Force for the Acceleration of Rehabilitation and Reconstruction (PRR Task Force) ensures that the distribution of Shelter Waiting Funds (DTH) for communities affected by natural disasters in a number of areas of Sumatra has been implemented.

Head of the PRR Task Force, Tito Karnavian, explained that this social assistance was provided specifically targeting survivors who had lost their homes or for those whose homes were seriously damaged.

Meanwhile, the realization of aid distribution at the regional level has now reached 94% in Aceh Province, 99% in North Sumatra and 97% in West Sumatra.

"The distribution of housing waiting funds in Aceh has reached 94%, in North Sumatra 99%, and West Sumatra 97%. This is specifically for seriously damaged or lost people. They can choose to rent, rent, or live in their family's house," said Tito on the agenda of the Sumatra Post-Disaster Recovery Task Force Coordination Meeting, Wednesday (18/2/2026).

Tito detailed that the amount of the Residential Waiting Fund assistance disbursed was IDR 600,000 per month for a period of three months, so that each head of family received a total of IDR 1.8 million.

These funds are provided as compensation so that the burden of temporary housing costs for residents whose homes were destroyed or lost can be accommodated by the state. Where, the distribution of these funds was carried out simultaneously in 25 districts and cities last week.

Also Read

Meanwhile, in its implementation, the PRR Task Force coordinates with the National Disaster Management Agency (BNPB) which holds technical data and detailed figures for beneficiaries in the field to ensure accurate distribution.

"The residential waiting fund is IDR 600,000 x 3 to IDR 1.8 million. Yesterday last week we implemented it simultaneously in 25 regencies/cities, the figure is that the head of BNPB understands," he concluded.

Previously, the Head of the BNPB Data and Information Center, Abdul Muhari, explained that the total budget that would be distributed for the DTH program was IDR 32.7 billion for 18,198 families from 40 districts/cities.

Abdul explained that DTH was given to families who did not receive temporary housing (Huntara) because according to him not all families wanted to live in shelters.

In its report, Aceh Province received a DTH budget allocation of IDR 20.8 billion for 111,586 families, North Sumatra IDR 8.1 billion for 4,502 families, and West Sumatra IDR 3.7 billion for 2,110 families.

"So those who receive DTH do not receive shelter, those who enter shelter do not receive DTH and from the amount that has been received, we have allocated a budget of IDR 32 [billion] or 18,198 [KK]," he said.

Bisnis.com, JAKARTA — Pemerintah melalui Satuan Tugas Percepatan Rehabilitasi dan Rekonstruksi (Satgas PRR) memastikan penyaluran Dana Tunggu Hunian (DTH) bagi masyarakat korban bencana alam di sejumlah wilayah Sumatra telah dilaksanakan.

Kasatgas PRR, Tito Karnavian menjelaskan bahwa bantuan sosial ini diberikan secara khusus menyasar para penyintas yang kehilangan tempat tinggal atau bagi mereka yang rumahnya mengalami kategori rusak berat.

Adapun, realisasi penyaluran bantuan di tingkat daerah tercatat saat ini telah mencapai 94% di Provinsi Aceh, 99% di Sumatra Utara, dan 97% di Sumatra Barat.

"Penyaluran dana tunggu hunian di Aceh sudah 94%, di sumut 99%, dan sumbar 97%. Ini khusus untuk rusak berat atau hilang. Mereka bisa memilih kontrak, sewa, atau tinggal di rumah keluarganya," kata Tito dalam agenda Rapat Koordinasi Satgas emulihan Pasca Bencana Sumatra, Rabu (18/2/2026).

Tito merinci, besaran bantuan Dana Tunggu Hunian yang dikucurkan adalah Rp600.000 per bulan untuk jangka waktu tiga bulan, sehingga setiap kepala keluarga menerima total dana sebesar Rp1,8 juta. 

Dana tersebut diberikan sebagai kompensasi agar beban biaya tempat tinggal sementara bagi warga yang rumahnya hancur atau hilang dapat terakomodasi oleh negara. Di mana, penyaluran dana tersebut telah dilakukan secara serentak di 25 kabupaten dan kota pada pekan lalu.

Sementara dalam pelaksanaannya, Satgas PRR berkoordinasi dengan Badan Nasional Penanggulangan Bencana (BNPB) yang memegang data teknis serta angka rincian penerima manfaat di lapangan guna menjamin ketepatan distribusi.

“Dana tunggu hunian Rp600.000 x 3 jadi Rp1,8 juta. Kemarin minggu lalu kita laksanakan serempak di 25 Kab/Kota, angkanya kepala BNPB yang paham,” pungkasnya.

Sebelumnya, Kepala Pusat Data dan Informasi BNPB, Abdul Muhari menjelaskan total anggaran yang akan disalurkan untuk program DTH sebesar Rp32,7 miliar untuk 18.198 KK yang berasal dari 40 kabupaten/kota. 

Abdul menjelaskan DTH diberikan kepada keluarga yang tidak menerima hunian sementara (Huntara) karena menurutnya tidak semua keluarga ingin tinggal di huntara.

Dalam laporannya, Provinsi Aceh mendapat alokasi anggaran DTH sebesar Rp20,8 miliar untuk 111.586 KK, Sumatra Utara Rp8,1 miliar untuk 4.502 KK, dan Sumatra Barat Rp3,7 miliar untuk 2.110 KK.

"Jadi mereka yang menerima DTH tidak menerima huntara, mereka yang masuk ke huntara itu tidak menerima DTH dan dari jumlah yang sudah masuk ini, kita sudah mengalokasikan anggaran sebesar Rp32 [miliar] atau 18.198 [KK]," katanya.

title: Property Sector Pulse Weakens, Middle Class Purchasing Power Falls
content:
Bisnis.com, JAKARTA – The Indonesian property sector continues to show slowing performance, with residential prices recorded as continuing to decline since 2024.

The Bank for International Settlements noted that residential property prices in Indonesia fell from 1.46% in the third quarter of 2024 to 0.8% in the third quarter of 2025. In fact, according to the Indonesian Society of Appraisers (Mappi), property growth in Indonesia has reached 6-7%.

Mappi administrator, Harizul Akbar Nazwar, assesses that there is a shift in trends in the property market. Now, instead of relying on expectations, the property market is driven by reality and needs.

"So as a primary need, it is definitely sought after. But the market has apparently moved. From what was previously community-driven to now infrastructure-driven," explained Harizul in the Factory Hub Business podcast program, some time ago.

Currently, people choose to buy property considering distance, adequate infrastructure facilities, and easy access to transportation compared to expensive property as an investment asset.

Harizul said that the property sector is one of the most important sectors for Indonesia, considering that its contribution to gross domestic product (GDP) reaches 14-15%. Therefore, according to him, property must be seen as a policy tool, not just an economic sector.

Also Read

So, it is not surprising that the government is pouring pressure on the property sector with various incentives. The lure of this policy includes people's business credit, aka KUR Housing, with a 5% government interest subsidy, as well as an extension of the 100% government-borne value added tax incentive (VAT DTP) until 2027 which applies to houses priced up to IDR 5 billion.

"Even though our interest rate trend is also relatively down, now at 4.75 basis points and has fallen by around, if I'm not mistaken, almost 1% compared to last year, [but] it still feels insufficient," said Harizul.

Even these policy efforts have not yet yielded results. The sluggish property sector is also caused by structural problems, such as weakening purchasing power and economic uncertainty.

"But there is one paradigm that is quite interesting. There is also a trend of young people now avoiding home ownership," added Harizul.

Indonesia itself is still facing a shortage, aka a backlog of home ownership of up to 15 million units. Regarding this, the government offers a solution through the 3 million houses program.

However, once again, developers are worried that people will not be interested in buying properties that have already been built. Harizul also encouraged the government to not only improve the supply side, but also the demand side.

On the other hand, the middle class group is increasingly squeezed because it does not have as solid a foundation as the upper class, but also does not receive as much assistance from the government as low-income people (MBR) receive. In fact, this segment is targeted as potential consumers.

According to Harizul, people, especially the younger generation, consider long-term risks, for example income and ability to pay in installments. "These things make people, especially first home buyers, relatively less confident in deciding whether to buy now or not."

In order to realize the success of the 3 million houses program, Harizul encouraged the government to issue measurable policies with optimal outreach to the community.

Meanwhile, from the developer's side, he suggested that non-cash incentives be prepared for the community. For example, price cuts or conversion into household appliances for the lower middle class.
